question: Damnit. Sebastian pears out his window. Across the courtyard, a light comes on in a neighboring window. He sees a BRUNETTE, mid-twenties, absolutely stunning, enter her living room. The Brunette thumbs through the mail, tosses it and then begins to undress. Sebastian loans over to the window, getting interested. But when the brunette reaches her bra and panties, she crosses to the window and lowers her shades. SEBASTIAN Damnit. Sebastian leans back in his chair and closes his eyes. He s obviously tired. He opens his eyes and stares up at the ceiling. Painted across the white matte finish in big red letters is a brief reminder - You Should Be Working. Sebastian sighs, leans forward and begins pecking away again. I am a goddamn genius. He hits a few more keys and a telephone keypad appears on the screen. He dials.
answer: Sebastian, do you know what time it is?

question: You know Da Vinci never slept. Said it was waste of time.
answer: What is it this time? INTERCUT

question: Who s that? Linda pulls the camera off the top of the of the computer screen and positions it so Sebastian can t see the bed.
answer: Not your business. Not anymore.

question: Touche.
answer: So you calling about anything in particular, or were you just hoping to catch me sleeping in the nude?

question: I cracked the reversion. Upon hearing this, Linda receives a jolt of adrenaline.
answer: You cracked it?

question: Look at this. Sebastian hits a couple of keys. A moment later the molecular structure appears on Linda s computer. Watch this.
answer: You sure?

question: 91% sure.
answer: Eleven months with no progress and you suddenly come up with it out of the blue? How?

question: The usual. Coffee and twinkies.
answer: I hate you.

question: I know. You think you could hunt down Matt and get to the lab early. I want Isabelle prepped for a live test.
answer: Yeah, I think I can find him. What are you going to do?

question: Well y know. It s daylight in Switzerland. I gotta call the Nobel Committee and tell them to get our prizes ready. See you in a few. ON LINDA S COMPUTER SCREEN as Sebastian clicks off. Linda crosses to her bed, and shakes the guy awake.
answer: Hey... come on. DR. MATTHEW KENSINGTON, late 20s too, stirs from under sheets.

question: Hey... come on. DR. MATTHEW KENSINGTON, late 20s too, stirs from under sheets.
answer: What?

question: Sebastian just called. We gotta get to the lab. Matt bolts up.
answer: Shit! You didn t tell him I was here, did you?

question: Give me some credit, will ya.
answer: So what s the rush?

question: He cracked reversion. Matt pulls his jeans on.
answer: Wanna ride down?

question: We better take our own cars.
answer: You re gonna have to tell him about us eventually.

question: Morning, sir.
answer: Morning, Ed.

question: Your team s in early. Something special going on?
answer: Sorry, Ed. You know the rules. Sebastian presses his thumb against a glass screen. A laser reads his print. Scan readout

question: Have a good day, sir.
answer: Caine zero zero two seven. ELEVATOR Authorization verified. Good morning, Dr. Caine. The elevator descends with a groaning hum. It passes below us and keeps descending into the belly of the earth, the shaft goes down forever.

question: Isabelle ... The woodchips on the floor shift and suddenly the Plexiglas steams up right in front of Matt s face. The Plexiglas begins to shake violently. MATT Calm down baby. Calm down. It s okay... Matt takes a pair of thermal goggles from his belt and pulls them down over his eyes. THERMAL POV - A rather large heat signature, ape-like in shape, rattles about the cage. Matt slowly unlatches the Plexiglas door and reaches inside. MATT It s okay, baby. It s okay. I m not going to hurt you. Come here. THERMAL POV - he reaches out to the creature. He grabs hold of it, firmly. Stroking it. The creature COOS. Matt reaches for a hypo and brings it up to the creature. MATT Just hold still. Something clamps down on his hand, breaking his skin. Blood erupts in a bite pattern. MATT Ow, shit. Matt drops the hypo and falls back. The cage door flies open and something runs out. Matt pulls himself up to see the heat signature running down the hallway. He turns around to see another heat signature coming at him. Matt pulls off his goggles to see Linda coming up the Corridor.
answer: You okay?

question: She bit me.
answer: Yeah. She s become a lot more aggressive in the last few days. Linda takes the goggles from Matt. LINDA Go take care of that bite. I ll get her.

question: And give you a chance to pull ahead? Never. Linda opens a lock-box at the end of the hallway and pulls out a two tranquilizer guns. She hands one to Matt. Shh. Be vewy, vewy quiet. I m hunting simians. heheheheh.
answer: Knock it off. Isabelle! THERMAL POV - Dark hallway. Movement. A red shimmering heat signature. It comes running at Linda. HOWLING. Linda fires. A T-DART flies. Thwack... It stops in mid-air. Then falls. But it doesn t hit the floor. Instead, it stops inches above the ground. THERMAL POV - the heat signature lies in a heap at Linda s feet.

question: Good shootin , Tex.
answer: What s that make it?

question: I m still ahead. 6 to 5. Like a smug gunfighter, Linda blows imaginary smoke from the top of her tranquilizer gun.
answer: But I m catching up.

question: Can I have a word?
answer: Most normal people say good morning.

question: Don t you think you should test the protocol on the liver samples before you inject Isabelle?
answer: How many tissue samples have we successfully regressed? Hundreds, right? How many have gone on to work on the full system? None.

question: That s beside the point.
answer: No, that is the point. I m not going to waste six months of my life on an outmoded testing procedure. This thing works. I know it. I feel it. Linda comes down the corridor, listening in on the tail end of the conversation.

question: Fine. You can mop up afterward.
answer: You think I m going to kill Isabelle?

question: Kill? More like liquefy.
answer: Sarah, thank you for your opinion, but I m the project leader. Understand? She says ...

question: Yes, Sir. ... but somehow it feels like Fuck you. She storms off. Sebastian turns to Linda.
answer: How did you ever convince me to hire her?

question: How did you ever convince me to hire her?
answer: You said you wanted the beat vet in the country.

question: Yeah, well she cares more about the animals than the research.
answer: Maybe that s why she s so good.

question: We should celebrate.
answer: To the finest research team I've ever known. Hey...

question: I thought you'd gone.
answer: Where would I go?

question: A little "I am become death... the shatterer of worlds"?
answer: Something like that.

question: Since the day I met, all you wanted to do was change the world.
answer: Actually it does. I guess since you were there from the beginning, you know me better than anyone else on this godforsaken planet.

question: You're positively maudlin. You should be happy. Do you have any idea what you've accomplished?
answer: Yeah... but I was working so hard, I didn't realize I'd have no one to share it with.

question: But now... But now, we feel we are closer than ever to resolving this issue. We've been experimenting with a new regression formula that looks rather promising. A FOUR STAR GENERAL leans forward. Sir? Shouldn't be more than another year, Sir.
answer: Yo. Reality check! What the hell was that about?

question: Keep your voice down.
answer: The protocol works. Why'd you tell them it didn't?

question: I wasn't ready for them to know.
answer: But they're the oversight committee. They're supposed to know.

question: How are we gonna find out? Besides, we've succeeded with a gorilla and their DNA is 98% the same as humans. And the 2% is not that significant.
answer: Sebastian ... humans can talk, build houses and cook in microwave ovens. Gorilla's live in trees. That's a helluva 2% if you ask me.

question: We're all concerned. I know that. But if we're gonna move forward ever, this is something we have to do.
answer: Why you? Why not one of us?

question: Come in.
answer: In the past six years, I've never once challenged your decisions, but this ... Sebastian. I don't think you should do this.

question: You don't understand.
answer: Oh please. How long were we together? You must've said it a million times ... Nobody knows who built the lunar lander. All they remember in the first man on the moon.

question: Lin, trust me... nothing's going to happen.
answer: He refuses to listen to reason.

question: He refuses to listen to reason.
answer: Can we talk about this later? I'm trying to make love to you.

question: Sorry. I just can't let it go.
answer: I know how you're feeling. Hell, he and I've been friends since freshman year.

question: So how can we let him do this?
answer: What if you were given the opportunity to be the first person on ,Mars, would you go?

question: In a heartbeat.
answer: What if they didn't know whether or not they could get you home?

question: Let me ask another question.
answer: Is about who gets to be on top?

question: Is the human race really ready for what we're doing?
answer: Why do you always get philosophical before we're about to get physical?

question: No really. Is it ready? We're barrelling down a road that begs moral and ethical questions that I don't think we can answer.
answer: They said the same thing about the bomb. They said we'd never survive the nuclear age... but here we are.

question: This night is still young. I mean, when you think about it, it's creepy. Do we really want to live in a world where people can just disappear in the blink of an eye?
answer: We made our deal with the devil years ago. Might as well stick around to cash in.

question: We made our deal with the devil years ago. Might as well stick around to cash in.
answer: Yes?

question: We're ready.
answer: Okay.

question: It's not too late to back out. I'm happy to take your place.
answer: No. I'm ready.

question: Nervous?
answer: A little.

question: Ever tell you the one about Superman and Wonder Woman?
answer: I don't think so.

question: Fine.
answer: Pulse 88, BP 140 over 95. A bit elevated.

question: To be expected.
answer: No reason for concern. He's ready.

question: S'okay. You nodded off.
answer: His breathing's hypnotic. How long's it been?

question: Seventeen hours.
answer: Where are the others?

question: In the lab crunching numbers. We've got enough data there for two lifetimes of research.
answer: I keep looking at that hole, wondering if he's really there.

question: The lights! Turn off the goddamn lights! Ah Christ!
answer: Your eyelids are transparent.

question: So I ... I'm...
answer: Yes.

question: My arms. I can.. where? ... I can feel them...
answer: Your arms ... your whole body... It worked, Sebastian. It worked.

question: Mirror. I ... I want to see.
answer: Over here in the corner.

question: I ... It's hard to think.
answer: It was painful?

question: At first... but then everything went black. I couldn't see or hear or feel anything. It was all just black... like I wasn't connected.
answer: Your system received quite a shock.

question: At least my senses are starting to return... You're wearing your Shalimar, aren't you?
answer: Sebastian.

question: This is weird. I'm looking through myself at the floor. I'm looking right through myself. I can't tell ...
answer: Sebastian?

question: It's late. Time you got some rest.
answer: Just a little longer.

question: Hate to pull rank, but you're my patient now and you need rest. We've got a busy day tomorrow.
answer: Fine.

question: We've set up a thermal camera for observation and I've arranged one of us to be here 24/7 in case you need anything. The team's gonna be on alpha- call alert for the duration. If anything goes wrong, we can all be here within...
answer: Thirty minutes. Yes,,_I know. I wrote the procedure.

question: I was trying to be reassuring.
answer: You like this don't you?

question: What's that?
answer: Being in charge.

question: So, how was your first night?
answer: Restless. Hard to sleep when you can't close your eyes.

question: Yeah? What'd you do?
answer: Got up a couple of times. Knocked about.

question: Yeah, Sarah mentioned you weren't in your cubicle. She said she called you over the intercom and you didn't respond.
answer: I guess I didn't hear. I had the radio on.

question: It'd be helpful to us if you'd tell whoever's on duty where you're going to. I mean, if something were to happen, we'd want to know where to find you.
answer: I didn't think it was a problem.

question: Sebastian? Goddamnit.
answer: You've no idea how much fun I've had. I'm going to hate going back.

question: That's what worries me.?
answer: How so?

question: What happens when we turn the project over to the Army. Ever wonder how much fun they're gonna have?
answer: Maybe we won't give it to them. His voice comes from behind her now.

question: Stop it, Sebastian. It's not funny.
answer: Well, don't do it for me. Do it for science.

question: Grow up.
answer: Oh well. Missed your big chance.

question: Just got the tissue sample results. Cellular cohesion is stable.
answer: Guess so. I was just thinking about the Apollo missions. Y'know? Grissom, White and Chaffee... What it was like for them on that launch pad that day, thinking they were gonna reach the stars only to burn to death.

question: Sometimes the test pilots make history. Sometimes the planes crash and people die.
answer: But he didn't die, did he? What if we can't bring him back? What then?

question: It's just a little hitch is all. He'll be the first to tell that he'll crack it and I'm sure he will. It'll just take time. Listen, let's got out of here. We could drive up to the old observatory. We'll take some wine and go count the stars and forget all this for awhile.
answer: No. I want to be here for him.

question: You look worried. It must've been bad.
answer: You almost died.

question: Well, remember your Nietchze. Whatever doesn't kill me, makes me stronger.
answer: I should be making you feel better. Not vice versa.

question: Dr. Caine. What's up?
answer: Just stopped by to let you know, I'm going out for a bit.

question: Going out? Hey wait a sec! What do you mean going out for a bit?
answer: If I don't get out of here, I'm gonna go crazy.

question: But you're not supposed to leave the compound.
answer: Why not?

question: That's the rule.
answer: Yes, but I made that rule. It's my rule and I'm changing it.

question: You can't just change it.
answer: Carter, I was suppose to be like this for three days. Three fucking days and I'll be damned if I'm going to spend the rest of my life as a prisoner in this godforsaken dump. Now I'm going out. I'll be back in a couple of hours. Okay?

question: He could be anywhere. Hell he could be right behind us.
answer: I'll meet you at the lab. I'm gonna swing by his place, just in case.

question: See you there.
answer: I don't want him to see.

question: I got a little stir crazy, so I went to my apartment to pick up some stuff.
answer: Bullshit! I went to your apartment and I happen to know you did a helluva lot more than pick some stuff up.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: You, of all people How could you?

question: Just what did you see in my apartment?
answer: I saw your face and your clothes.

question: Don't make a mountain out of molehill. I didn't let anyone see me.
answer: That's not good enough. When you're outside the lab there are a thousand variables none of us can control. It's just not safe for you to be out there.

question: Come on, Linda. You don't expect me to be some kind of prisoner.
answer: You volunteered for this, Sebastian. You knew going in there could be consequences. For the security of this project, I'm gonna have to ask you to confine yourself to the compound.

question: I'm still Project Leader, Linda. It's my decision to make.
answer: You're right. It's your decision. But if you leave the compound again, I'll notify the oversight committee. Then they can make the decision. You understand?

question: Hold still.
answer: How much blood do you think you've taken so far?

question: Not enough to worry about.
answer: Every day... feels like you're sucking me dry.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: The shoe being on the other foot. You getting to run things.

question: I didn't ask for this, Caine. But when a classified experiment disappears in the middle of the night, someone's gotta run the show. Look, I know how hard this has been for you.
answer: Don't patronize me. And for the record, you've got no idea what it's like. I get up every morning and you people stick needles in me. You bombard me with radiation until I vomit. And then at six it's over for you. You get to go home. But Sebastian is still here. Sebastian can't leave, or else. That's the worst part, you know. Here I have this ... this GIFT and I can't even use it.

question: Now it's a gift?
answer: You're goddamn right it's a gift. And if you weren't so goddamned short sighted, I'd be out there right now trying to master it.

question: Where're you going?
answer: Looks like I'm going nowhere.

question: Want to talk about it?
answer: No.

question: "We are the hollow men, the stuffed men, headpieces filled with straw."
answer: Funny, huh? I've become a literal metaphor.

question: I don't want to fight you. I just want what's best for the program.
answer: I know. And you being right doesn't make it any easier for me.

question: You can be scared. That's okay.
answer: I'm not scared of being stuck this way. With a little more make-up and practice, I could... ... pass. Y'know, get by in the world. But the testing...

question: You're talking like you've given up. It's only been a few months.
answer: What if it's years? I don't know how much more testing I can take.

question: Sebastian crosses underneath the camera... just out of its range... reaches up and using a screwdriver, unscrews the access panel. He scans the electronics and attaches two alligator clips to wires on the circuit board.
answer: The video image of the Recovery Chamber flickers slightly, before returning to normal.

question: Sebastian rises and begins to peel off his latex.
answer: Again, Sebastian's POV as he pushes through the open door of the observation room. We see Frank sorting through various computer readouts, highlighting certain coding sequences.

question: The rewired security camera stares down at the empty bed.
answer: Frank glances over at the video monitor. He can see Sebastian's heat signature lying in the bed.

question: I restructured the third genome on your radiated protein strand. Thought you might want to take look.
answer: Cook up a batch and let's see where we go.

question: I thought you'd want to take a look at it.
answer: I trust you. Now if you'll excuse me, I need to have my head examined.

question: When you were a kid, you ever dream about being invisible?
answer: Sure... all the time.

question: What did you imagine you'd do?
answer: The usual.

question: What's the usual?
answer: Hanging out in the girl's locker room. Kicking Jimmy Margiani's ass.

question: Jimmy Margiani?
answer: School asshole. Drove a red Trans Am. Back then, I was the size of a small planet and made a rather large target.

question: Ever think up anything along the grand scale?
answer: Sure. World domination. Manipulating stock markets, consolidating a political power base. But those are more recent fantasies.

question: Sure. World domination. Manipulating stock markets, consolidating a political power base. But those are more recent fantasies.
answer: And what if it weren't fantasy? What if you were out there in the world and could do whatever you wanted with no consequences whatsoever. How far would go? I mean... if it were real?

question: I don't know, man. Out in the real world... I mean, there's a responsibility...
answer: Let's say you saw a woman with amazing tits. Would you brush against them?

question: Hell, I try and do that now.
answer: Human nature. So if you could get away with more, would you do more?

question: I read that in a survey at a major university they asked college students "Would you steal if you were guaranteed to get away with it?" 82% said yes.
answer: Eighty two percent? Makes you wonder if the world's ready for what we're doing.

question: So, Doc what did you do?
answer: What do you mean?

question: When you were out.
answer: I just walked around. Y'know.

question: Aw, you just walked around? Come on. There's more, right?
answer: Like what?

question: Man, I'd be walking up to people saying shit like "This is God, go,get a haircut." Or hanging out in the changing room at Victoria's Secret.
answer: Kind of sophomoric, don't you think. Besides, it was late and I wasn't out that long.

question: Well, did you see anybody?
answer: There was this one girl.

question: Yeah? And did you mess with her?
answer: Naw...

question: Be quiet! Shhhh. It's Nobody-It's nothing.
answer: You awake?

question: I am now.
answer: Notice anything unusual last night.

question: No. Why?
answer: Franklin Three. He's dead.

question: His neck was broken and his windpipe collapsed.
answer: How'd that happen?

question: I thought maybe you could tell me.
answer: Sarah... You saying I had something to do with it?

question: He was alive last night when I left and he was dead this morning. And you were the only one down here.
answer: I was in my room all night.

question: Any big plans for tonight?
answer: Quiet night at home. Maybe a book.

question: Really? Whatever happened to that guy your were seeing?
answer: He's still in the picture. Why?

question: Being locked down here, I'm forced to live vicariously. Someday you'll have to tell me what he's like.
answer: Maybe someday I will. See you in the morning.

question: Either way, we aren't equipped to handle this. We have to inform the committee.
answer: What if he doesn't come back?

question: They'll go after him. Who has tonight's shift?
answer: I do.

question: When did he say held call?
answer: He's probably meeting with the committee trying to figure out what to do.

question: I'm gonna call him.
answer: What?

question: He's dead. Drowned in his pool last night.
answer: Let me see that.

question: I'll be right back with help. Foster One Delta Eight Three Five. That's a first. Foster One Delta Eight Three Five.
answer: Let me try mine. Kensington Two Romeo One Five Nine.

question: Oh the system is fine. It's just I'm just extraordinary.
answer: What is it?

question: There's nothing wrong with the system. Our codes have been removed.
answer: Removed? By who?

question: Okay, Sebastian. Fun's over. Tell us where you are.
answer: I'm sorry. But I can't lot you turn me in.

question: Sebastian... where are you?
answer: You have no idea what it's like. The power of it. The freedom. I can't let that go.

question: C'mon Sebastian. You're scaring me. Tell me where you are and we can talk about it.
answer: There's nothing to talk about. See ... I've done things that can't be undone.

question: Sebastian?
answer: This is bad.

question: There's something over there.
answer: What happened?

question: She was strangled. Multiple blows to her head.
answer: Intercom... the phone lines. They're dead.

question: Gimme that.
answer: What the fuck is going on here?

question: He probably just stopped moving.
answer: It's me.

question: Do you have anything?
answer: Nothing.

question: How did he get by us?
answer: He couldn't.

question: Sebastian! We're here to help. Sebastian.
answer: There. Behind those pipes. He's not moving.

question: We see him. But he's not responding. The heat signature doesn't move. C'mon... C'mon...
answer: Covered.

question: What the... Looks like... looks like we're pumping out heat... No fucking shit!
answer: H...Help... MMmmphg

question: Goddamnit. The doors are closing. He's shutting me in.
answer: He's coming right at you!

question: Where?
answer: Twenty, maybe thirty feet.

question: Goddamnit, I got thermals all over the place. Eight, maybe ten of them. Must be ghosts.
answer: Those signatures ... they're coming from the heating vents.

question: I'm starting to lose resolution on my thermals.
answer: Get out of there!

question: Get out of there!
answer: If the room temperature is the same as his body temperature, thermal visors'll be no good.

question: I'm going!
answer: Linda...it's not safe.

question: That's why I'm going. Corridor eight is clear. Get Carter to the lab. We'll meet you there.
answer: But...

question: This way.
answer: He'll be okay.

question: It's pretty severe. We have to get him to the lab.
answer: He's got to be okay.

question: He was going to kill me.
answer: I know. He's gone.

question: We've got to got out of here.
answer: Habitats.

question: His pulse is faint.
answer: Where are you going?

question: This'll hold him but he needs blood.
answer: But...

question: Supply is right down the hall. I'll be two seconds.
answer: Sarah, wait for the others

question: Ahh! Shit!
answer: He's let the animals out. It wasn't him we were tracking.

question: It won't kill me unless it gets infected. You?
answer: Me .... Don't ask about me. If he freed all the animals, we could have dozens running around the lab.

question: So he could be anywhere right now.
answer: Get to the lab, lock the goddamn doors and pray to God Frank can reprogram the elevator.

question: Sarah! Sarah! Goddamnit. Stay with me now. Don't you let up... Sarah! Sarah!
answer: Where is she?

question: She went to the supply room. Carter needed blood.
answer: I said no one goes anywhere alone.

question: She didn't listen.
answer: He's dead.

question: Sebastian!
answer: I would say that what I am experiencing is psychological awareness. I like you being in complete and absolute control.

question: You goddamn bastard! You goddamn bastard. You're gonna pay for this. I'm going to bring you back to visibility and then I'm going throw your ass in jail.
answer: You're never gonna bring me back Linda. I never want to come back.

question: Fuck you!
answer: Or maybe I'll fuck you. One last time for old times sake.

question: Lin...
answer: You feel that?

question: A little...
answer: Your losing blood, but he didn't hit the vitals. Goddamnit.

question: What're you doing?
answer: This is temporary.

question: Barely.
answer: Just keeps getting worse.

question: Linda holds the plug end of the extension cord. The other end is wrapped into a tight long coil. Linda looks for an outlet, but can't find one. She looks at the overhead lights.
answer: Sebastian enters, fully dressed. At a distance it'd be hard to tell his secret. He pulls several chemicals off the shelves. Then he pulls a tray of test tubes over and begins mixing.

question: Linda works on jerry rigging the two ends of the wire to the lightbulb, socket. Suddenly the coiled wire springs to life and flies against the nearest metal surface. She's made an electromagnet.
answer: Sebastian loads the filled test tubes into the centrifuge. Dozens of other vials are already slotted. He takes one of the left over vials, considers it a moment and then flings it over to the other side of the lab. The vial shatters and...

question: Caine. One One One One One.
answer: Sebastian!

question: You said it yourself, Lin. I shouldn't hold on to the past.
answer: Aaaaaaahhhh!

question: Oh God!
answer: You wanna see God? I'll show you God.

question: Oh God!
answer: Don't look.

question: Move!
answer: It's coming down!

question: C'mon. Before it slips.
answer: Sebastian, you fuck.

question: Get off me.
answer: No!
